function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) may not fully replace clinical testing for COVID-19 and may need to be used in conjunction with clinical testing.","Impact":"Misidentification of infected individuals and delayed response to outbreaks.","Mitigation":"Integration of WBE with clinical testing for comprehensive surveillance and response.","Technologies":"Data integration and analysis platforms for combining WBE and clinical testing data.","People":"Emergency response teams, healthcare providers, and public health authorities.","Owner":"Public health authorities, research institutions, and government agencies."},{"Description":"Limitations in global access to centrally collected wastewater for WBE may restrict its effectiveness in certain regions.","Impact":"Inadequate surveillance and response in resource-limited areas, potentially leading to uncontrolled spread of COVID-19.","Mitigation":"Integration of latrine sampling into global health surveillance systems to expand WBE coverage in resource-poor regions.","Technologies":"Development of sampling and analysis techniques for decentralized wastewater sources.","People":"Global health organizations, aid agencies, and governments in resource-limited areas.","Owner":"Global health organizations and research institutions."},{"Description":"Diverting resources from clinical testing to WBE may affect the accuracy and timeliness of COVID-19 surveillance and response.","Impact":"Reduced capacity for clinical testing and potential delays in identifying and containing COVID-19 outbreaks.","Mitigation":"Optimization of resource allocation with a balanced approach to clinical testing and WBE, leveraging cost-efficient technologies for both.","Technologies":"Cost-effective testing and analysis methods for clinical and wastewater samples.","People":"Public health authorities, healthcare providers, and policymakers.","Owner":"Government agencies, public health authorities, and research institutions."}]}
